title: How to Build a Reclaimed Wood Crate

parts.name: Preparing the Wood for Your Crate

steps.headline: Remove the tongues.
steps.description: Unless you're getting precut wood, you'll need to measure and cut the wood to the appropriate dimensions of your crate. Reclaimed tongue and groove barn wood is going to be used for this project. It is best to cut the tongues off the wood before measuring and cutting the wood to size. Carefully use your saw to remove the tongue from all of the reclaimed wood boards. (The tongue is the part of the wood pointed at in the image above.) Set the trimmed wood aside.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b5\/8inches.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b5\/8inches.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":404,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":666.7484662576687,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"}Cut the wood for the short ends of your crate.
steps.description: In this step you will be measuring and cutting the shorter ends of your crate. Using your saw take one of the tongue trimmed boards and measure and cut the board into an 8" piece. You will need to repeat this process so that you will have two 8" pieces which will be used for the short ends of your crate. Set these two 8" long pieces of wood aside.

steps.headline: Cut the wood for the long sides.
steps.description: In this step you will be cutting the long pieces used to make the longer sides and bottom of the crate. Measure, mark, and cut a piece of tongue trimmed wood to 13 1/4". You will need to make at least three 13 1/4" boards.

steps.headline: Rip the wood.
steps.description: To create the thinner pieces of wood needed to make the long slats for this project, we will be using a method called "ripping" which is a process that cuts the wood parallel to the grain. Set your table saw for a 3/8" inch cut. Place a piece of the 13 1/4" tongue trimmed wood on the table saw. Carefully push the wood towards the blade. Once the saw has cut into the wood about an inch use a push stick and carefully guide the wood through the blade until fully cut. Make sure the wood is far enough from the blade, then carefully pick the wood up. Flip over the piece of wood over to the side that has not been cut and repeat the instructions for this step. You are going to need to rip two of the 13 1/4" pieces of wood. This will give you four 3/8" thick boards.

steps.headline: Cut the long wood into slats.
steps.description: After cutting and ripping the wood into 13 1/4" pieces we need to cut them into 1 3/4 wide slats. Set the table saw to 1 1/4". Take one of the boards and use the push stick to carefully slide the wood through the blade. Cut the board two more times till you have a total of three 1 1/4" width slats. Cut all the ripped boards. This will give you twelve 1 3/4" wide slats to use for the crate.

steps.headline: Build the sides of the crate.
steps.description:
Now that we have our wood prepared it will take no time at all to build this beautiful decretive crate. Gather all of your cut and trimmed wood that you have prepared for your crate. Using a staple gun with 1" staples, staple one of the 1 3/4" wide slats vertically on the edge of one of the 8" end pieces. One to two staples should hold each slat into place. (image above) {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e8/Jjkkhj.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e8/Jjkkhj.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":611,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1009.1803278688525,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Take another slat and carefully staple it on the same side but opposite end. (image above) {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/43/Threeslats.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/43/Threeslats.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":621,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1026.2032085561498,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Take a third slat and staple it directly in between the other two slats on that same side. (image above) {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6d/Si63465de.jpg/460px-Si63465de.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/6/6d/Si63465de.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":379,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":625.4166666666666,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Take the second 8" board and staple the other ends of the three slats on to it. If you are making a bigger or smaller crate just make sure the slats are evenly spaced before stapling them onto the 8" board. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/02/2side.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/02/2side.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":636,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1051.4110429447853,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Flip the crate over so the slats are resting on the table and carefully staple three more slats onto this side. Follow the same instructions from step 8 for this side. (image above)

steps.headline: Build the bottom of the crate.
steps.description:
For this step you will need to change the staples in your stapler to 1 3/4". Evenly space and staple the slats onto the groove side of the wood. Make sure to aim directly in the groove of the wood. (image above) {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/52\/Dgsdgs.jpg\/460px-Dgsdgs.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/5\/52\/Dgsdgs.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":564,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":931.2910284463895,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"} It will take five wooden 13/4" slats to cover the bottom of this crate.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d3\/BropeDsmes.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/d3\/BropeDsmes.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":377,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":623.485254691689,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
\nLicense: Creative Commons<\/a>\n<\/p><\/div>"}Add rope handles.
steps.description: This step is optional. Its important to find the perfect spot to place your rope handles. Doing so will ensure a better look and your crate will not go lopsided when being carried. Measure on one of the 8" short ends and find your center and use a pencil to mark it. Measure from the side of the crate to that first mark and make a mark there. Follow the same instructions in this part but go in the opposite direction. This is where you will be drilling your holes. Making sure you are the same distance from the top of the crate for both holes, drill the two areas you marked. Cut the desired length for your handles. The rope used for this crate is 22 inches (55.9 cm) in length. Slide one end of the rope from the outside of the crate to the inside. Tie a knot on the inside of the crate at the end of your rope. Slide the other end of the rope from the outside of the crate to the inside and tie a knot on that end. You now have your first handle. Complete these same steps to make the handle for the other side.

steps.headline: Making a stain to give your crate an aged look.
steps.description: This part is optional as well. You should do this step only if you want your crate to have an aged and weathered look to it. Get a small plastic or glass container with a lid. Place a steel wool pad in the container. Take white distilled vinegar and pour it over the still wool pad. Cover the container with the lid and let it sit. The longer the mixture sits the more dramatic effect it will create. For most projects about 2 - 4 days is a sufficient amount of time to make the perfect stain. Take a paint brush and paint the mixture on the inside and outside of your crate. Let it dry for about an hour.

steps.headline: Decorate and enjoy.
steps.description: Personalize your crate however you'd like by painting, polyurethane, and/or just adding decorations and enjoy your beautiful handcrafted reclaimed wood decorative crate.

text:
Preparing the Wood for Your Crate Remove the tongues. Unless you're getting precut wood, you'll need to measure and cut the wood to the appropriate dimensions of your crate. Reclaimed tongue and groove barn wood is going to be used for this project. It is best to cut the tongues off the wood before measuring and cutting the wood to size. Carefully use your saw to remove the tongue from all of the reclaimed wood boards. (The tongue is the part of the wood pointed at in the image above.) Set the trimmed wood aside. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b5/8inches.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b5/8inches.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":404,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":666.7484662576687,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Cut the wood for the short ends of your crate. In this step you will be measuring and cutting the shorter ends of your crate. Using your saw take one of the tongue trimmed boards and measure and cut the board into an 8" piece. You will need to repeat this process so that you will have two 8" pieces which will be used for the short ends of your crate. Set these two 8" long pieces of wood aside. Cut the wood for the long sides. In this step you will be cutting the long pieces used to make the longer sides and bottom of the crate. Measure, mark, and cut a piece of tongue trimmed wood to 13 1/4". You will need to make at least three 13 1/4" boards. Rip the wood. To create the thinner pieces of wood needed to make the long slats for this project, we will be using a method called "ripping" which is a process that cuts the wood parallel to the grain. Set your table saw for a 3/8" inch cut. Place a piece of the 13 1/4" tongue trimmed wood on the table saw. Carefully push the wood towards the blade. Once the saw has cut into the wood about an inch use a push stick and carefully guide the wood through the blade until fully cut. Make sure the wood is far enough from the blade, then carefully pick the wood up. Flip over the piece of wood over to the side that has not been cut and repeat the instructions for this step. You are going to need to rip two of the 13 1/4" pieces of wood. This will give you four 3/8" thick boards. Cut the long wood into slats. After cutting and ripping the wood into 13 1/4" pieces we need to cut them into 1 3/4 wide slats. Set the table saw to 1 1/4". Take one of the boards and use the push stick to carefully slide the wood through the blade. Cut the board two more times till you have a total of three 1 1/4" width slats. Cut all the ripped boards. This will give you twelve 1 3/4" wide slats to use for the crate. Building the Crate Build the sides of the crate. Now that we have our wood prepared it will take no time at all to build this beautiful decretive crate. Gather all of your cut and trimmed wood that you have prepared for your crate. Using a staple gun with 1" staples, staple one of the 1 3/4" wide slats vertically on the edge of one of the 8" end pieces. One to two staples should hold each slat into place. (image above) {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e8/Jjkkhj.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e8/Jjkkhj.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":611,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1009.1803278688525,"licensing":"

"} Take another slat and carefully staple it on the same side but opposite end. "} Take the second 8" board and staple the other ends of the three slats on to it. If you are making a bigger or smaller crate just make sure the slats are evenly spaced before stapling them onto the 8" board. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/02/2side.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/02/2side.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":636,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":1051.4110429447853,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader

"}Flip the crate over so the slats are resting on the table and carefully staple three more slats onto this side. Follow the same instructions from step 8 for this side. (image above) Build the bottom of the crate. For this step you will need to change the staples in your stapler to 1 3/4". Evenly space and staple the slats onto the groove side of the wood. Make sure to aim directly in the groove of the wood. (image above) {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Dgsdgs.jpg/460px-Dgsdgs.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/5/52/Dgsdgs.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":564,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":931.2910284463895,"licensing":"

"} It will take five wooden 13/4" slats to cover the bottom of this crate. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d3/BropeDsmes.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/d3/BropeDsmes.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":377,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":623.485254691689,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Add rope handles. This step is optional. Its important to find the perfect spot to place your rope handles. Doing so will ensure a better look and your crate will not go lopsided when being carried. Measure on one of the 8" short ends and find your center and use a pencil to mark it. Measure from the side of the crate to that first mark and make a mark there. Follow the same instructions in this part but go in the opposite direction. This is where you will be drilling your holes. Making sure you are the same distance from the top of the crate for both holes, drill the two areas you marked. Cut the desired length for your handles. The rope used for this crate is 22 inches (55.9 cm) in length. Slide one end of the rope from the outside of the crate to the inside. Tie a knot on the inside of the crate at the end of your rope. Slide the other end of the rope from the outside of the crate to the inside and tie a knot on that end. You now have your first handle. Complete these same steps to make the handle for the other side. Making a stain to give your crate an aged look. This part is optional as well. You should do this step only if you want your crate to have an aged and weathered look to it. Get a small plastic or glass container with a lid. Place a steel wool pad in the container. Take white distilled vinegar and pour it over the still wool pad. Cover the container with the lid and let it sit. The longer the mixture sits the more dramatic effect it will create. For most projects about 2 - 4 days is a sufficient amount of time to make the perfect stain. Take a paint brush and paint the mixture on the inside and outside of your crate. Let it dry for about an hour. Decorate and enjoy. Personalize your crate however you'd like by painting, polyurethane, and/or just adding decorations and enjoy your beautiful handcrafted reclaimed wood decorative crate.
